html:
Airtel Africa, an arm of Bharti Airtel, on Friday posted a profit after tax of $116 million, up 13.1 per cent from the year-ago period, buoyed by data and mobile money services. The company had reported a profit after tax of $103 million in the same period last financial year.

In the nine-month period ended December 31, Airtelâs Africa operations reported a net profit of $261 million, down 21.1 per cent from $331 million reported in the same period a year ago.

The underlying revenue grew 13.8 per cent to $2,870 million. âThis is due to our continued delivery of strong customer growth in Q3, despite the introduction mid-December of additional customer registration requirements in Nigeria. This has meant a temporary halt to the ability of all operators to onboard new users,â Raghunath Mandava, CEO, Airtel
